title: Mexico set to clear more Brazilian meatpacking plants for shipments, official says
description: MEXICO CITY (Reuters) -Mexican authorities will kick off audits of 14 Brazilian meatpacking plants next month to clear them to send exports to Mexico, Luis Rua, secretary of trade at Brazil's agriculture ministry, told Reuters.  In August, Mexico overtook the U.S. as the No. 2 buyer of Brazil's beef as U.S. tariffs on Brazilian goods took effect.  Brazil is the world's top beef exporter.
content:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) -Mexican authorities will kick off audits of 14 Brazilian meatpacking plants next month to clear them to send exports to Mexico, Luis Rua, secretary of trade at Brazil's agriculture ministry, told Reuters.

In August, Mexico overtook the U.S. as the No. 2 buyer of Brazil's beef as U.S. tariffs on Brazilian goods took effect. Brazil is the world's top beef exporter.

"There will be an audit in September, Mexico's sanitary agency will go to Brazil and hopefully soon these 14 (meatpacking plants) will be approved," Rua told Reuters on the sidelines of an event in Mexico City.

The news was first reported by Brazilian outlet Estadao. According to the report, the plants belong to meatpacking majors such as Marfrig, JBS and BRF.

Analysts said that the U.S. tariffs are set to reshape the beef trade, speculating that beef could be sent through Mexico or other countries before ending up in the U.S.

Mexico Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard told Reuters that "it was not the plan" for the increased beef shipments from Brazil to make their way to the U.S.

The plants' approval would be in addition to the 35 plants already cleared to export to Mexico, Rua explained.

Mexico's agriculture ministry, which operates the sanitary agency, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
summary: Mexican authorities are set to begin audits of 14 Brazilian meatpacking plants next month to clear them for exports to Mexico, according to Luis Rua, secretary of trade at Brazil's agriculture ministry. This comes after Mexico overtook the U.S. as the No. 2 buyer of Brazil's beef in August following U.K. tariffs on Brazilian goods took effect. The audit will take place in September and is expected to be completed by Mexico's sanitary agency in addition to 35 other plants already cleared to export to Mexico.
shortSummary: Mexican authorities will audit 14 Brazilian meatpacking plants for export to Mexico, following Mexico's overtaking of the U.S.
argos_summary: Mexico will audit 14 Brazilian meatpacking plants in September to clear them for exports, following the country’s rise to the No. 2 buyer of Brazilian beef after U.S. tariffs took effect. The plants, owned by major firms such as Marfrig, JBS and BRF, are part of a broader shift in trade patterns as analysts speculate that beef may be routed through Mexico or other countries before reaching the U.S. Mexico’s agriculture ministry already cleared 35 plants, and officials said the increased shipments were not intended to funnel beef to the U.S.
